discussion.content:
Agree with the answer:
1. response.status_code
2. response.headers.get('Link')
3. response.links['next']['url']

FR99 is correct. The correct URL from next page can be retrieved by using response.links['next']['url']. The use of response.headers.get('Link') could be easily replaced by an infinite loop like 'while True:' and it would be the same. They're just testing our knowledge here. The trick here is that once we reach the last page, response.links['next']['url'] within the 'try' context will fail and we'll move to the 'except' clause and the program will exit.

comments.content: That's true but it really should be response.links.get('next') which checks if there is a next link.

discussion.content:
Answer is correct: 
1. response.status_code
2. response.headers.get('Link')
3. response.links['next']['url']

Correct:
1. response.status_code
2. response.headers.get('Link')
3. response.links['next']['url']
I agree with FR99

You have "wireless" in the option

discussion.content:
The correct order is:

1. Api/v1/network-health
2. X-auth-token: token
3. category
4. Distribution

For healthDistriubution, the category parameter can only be "Access, Distribution, Router". Wireless is not an option here:

https://www.ciscolive.com/c/dam/r/ciscolive/emea/docs/2019/pdf/DEVNET-2878.pdf

choices.C: SSH through a bastion host and ansible_become method for privilege escalation.
choices.B: HTTPS through a repository and ansible_become method for privilege escalation.

discussion.content:
C is correct:
https://blog.networktocode.com/post/ansible-bastion-host/

Selected Answer: C
C is correct.

Selected Answer: C
Answer: C
For those that chose B, I will now explain why B is not applicable and C is the only valid choice.

The below link includes a table summarizing the connections available via Ansible to NXOS, for CLI (SSH) and NX-API (HTTPS)
Per the link below, NX-API (HTTPS) does not support enable mode. Only CLI (SSH) supports enable mode.

Reference: 
https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/network/user_guide/platform_nxos.html#connections-available

Selected Answer: C
agree with the answer

Selected Answer: C
Option A, HTTP through a web proxy, is not secure because HTTP is not an encrypted protocol. Option B, HTTPS through a repository and ansible_become method for privilege escalation, is not secure because the connections would not originate from a server in the same local network. Option D, XML-RPC through a web proxy, is not a supported method for connecting to an NX-OS switch

Selected Answer: C
Correct answer: C

SSH is used: ansible_ssh_common_args=ProxyCommand="ssh -W %h:%p ntc@bastion"

https://blog.networktocode.com/post/ansible-bastion-host/

I'd go with C. As the link in Johnno's answer says, a jump host can be used. Quite often, jump hosts are called bastions. Also, a (I assume git) repository cannot set up connections to other devices.

discussion.content: I think it's C

questions.question_text:
A local data center deployment using Cisco NX-OS switches is scaling and requires automatic configuration at scale. Configuration management must be set up for a Cisco NX-OS switch by using Ansible. The Ansible control server is currently located on a different subnet than the switch. The solution has these requirements:
✑ The transport protocol used must be encrypted.
✑ The connections must originate from a server in the same local network.
Enable mode must be supported.
//IMG//

Which connectivity method must be used?

discussion.content:
Answer is 'D'.
"Relational databases excel at handling highly structured data and provide support for ACID (Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, and Durability) transactions. Data is easily stored and retrieved using SQL queries. The structure can be scaled up quickly because adding data without modifying existing data is simple."
https://www.infoworld.com/article/3268871/how-to-choose-the-right-type-of-database-for-your-enterprise.html#:~:text=Server%20security%20tips.%20%5D-,Strengths,and%20retrieved%20using%20SQL%20queries.

Selected Answer: D
Yep, it's D

On point with FR99 on D as the answer:

Explanation:
In database systems, ACID (Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability) refers to a standard set of properties that guarantee database transactions are processed reliably. ACID is especially concerned with how a database recovers from any failure that might occur while processing a transaction. An ACID-compliant DBMS ensures that the data in the database remains accurate and consistent despite any such failures. All of the major relational DBMSs adhere to the ACID principles. They all include features that ensure that the data maintains consistent throughout software and hardware crashes, as well as any failed transactions.

questions.question_text: Which database type should be used with highly structured data and provides support for ACID transactions?
